importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the article was published, highlighting the current state of the Mariners' postseason campaign.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 1995 ALDS win over the Yankees is cited as pivotal in saving baseball in Seattle, establishing a historical context for the franchise’s legacy.
The 2001 ALCS game where Bret Boone hit a go-ahead homer is referenced as a benchmark for recent Mariners postseason excitement.
The current season's postseason progression and Suárez’s grand slam in 2025 mark a turning point in the Mariners’ long-standing quest to reach the World Series.

keyTakeAways: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, giving the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 win over the Toronto Blue Jays and moving them within one win of the World Series.
This is the second grand slam in Mariners postseason history, highlighting a rare and dramatic moment in franchise history.
The Mariners have not reached the World Series in over two decades, and this victory brings them within one win of achieving their first appearance in the Fall Classic.
The emotional response from fans and players, including Suárez bringing his daughters to the postgame press conference, underscores the cultural significance of the moment for Seattle.
Cal Raleigh’s game-tying homer in the eighth inning is a historic moment in Mariners postseason history, echoing the 2001 ALCS and signaling a resurgence in fan excitement.
The Mariners now lead the series 3-2 and will play Game 6 in Toronto on Sunday night.

namedEntities.name: Eugenio Suárez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Suárez’s grand slam in the eighth inning is the pivotal moment that propelled the Mariners to within one win of the World Series, marking a major turning point in the postseason.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners are the central subject of the article, with a history of not reaching the World Series, making this moment a historic milestone for the franchise.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are the opponent in the playoff series, and their earlier wins in Seattle created tension that Suárez’s performance broke.

namedEntities.name: Bryce Miller
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Miller was the Mariners’ starter who was removed in the fifth inning, setting the stage for the Blue Jays’ comeback and subsequent momentum shifts.

namedEntities.name: George Springer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Springer hit a two-out double in the fifth inning that tied the game, contributing to the Mariners’ resilience during the series.

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Clement drove in a run with a single in the sixth inning, helping to extend the Mariners’ lead during the game.

namedEntities.name: Cal Raleigh
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Raleigh’s eighth-inning home run tied the game and is a historic moment in Mariners postseason history, marking the first such homer in that inning since 2001.

namedEntities.name: Bret Boone
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Boone’s homer in Game 4 of the 2001 ALCS is referenced as a historical benchmark for Mariners postseason excitement and fan energy.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Judge
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Judge is tied with Raleigh in total home runs in a single postseason year, highlighting a current record in AL history.

namedEntities.name: New York Yankees
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Yankees are referenced in the historical context of the Mariners’ 1995 ALDS victory, which many believe saved baseball in Seattle.

namedEntities.name: American League Championship Series (ALCS)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ALCS is referenced in the context of both the 1995 and 2001 seasons, underscoring the significance of postseason outcomes in Mariners history.

namedEntities.name: World Series
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners have never reached the World Series, and this article highlights their current proximity to that historic milestone.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eugenio Suárez hit a game-changing grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, giving the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays and moving them within one win of their first World Series appearance in franchise history. The Mariners, who have never reached the Fall Classic, are now just one win away from achieving a milestone that has eluded them for over two decades. The dramatic moment, capped by Suárez’s emotional postgame remarks and the presence of his daughters, is seen as a turning point in the postseason. Cal Raleigh’s eighth-inning home run, the first in that inning since 2001, adds to the historic significance, while the article reflects on past playoff moments, including the 1995 ALDS win over the Yankees that helped save baseball in Seattle. The Mariners now lead the series 3-2 and will play Game 6 in Toronto on Sunday night.
title: Eugenio Suárez grand slam powers Seattle Mariners to within one win of first World Series
